prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(J=1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal here is to observe 12CO(J=1-0) over the whole system, to trace the total molecular gas mass.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
At the proposed resolution of 1"=300pc, we expect to observe Giant Molecular Associations (GMAs) which have typical mass of M(H2)=3*10^7 Msun (Rand et al. 1993). Assuming a Galactic CO-H2 conversion factor, the CO flux Sco can be estimated by M(H2)=2.2*10^3*D^2*Sco, where D is the distance, 61Mpc. Thus the expected CO flux is Sco = 3.7 [Jy km/s]. Assuming a typical velocity with of these structures to be 50km/s (Tosaki et al. 2007), the expected peak flux density if 74 mJy/beam. This is consistent with a separate estimation based on our OVRO data (Iono et al. 2009), which showed typical CO peaks of 20 [Jy km/s] at 5" (1.5kpc) resolution, corresponding to M(H2)=1.6*10^8 Msun. This means that the OVRO beam of 1.5kpc contained ~five 300pc GMAs within a 1.5kpc region, a reasonable number considering a typical separation between CO clouds of ~300pc (Scoville and Sanders, 1987).
For a S/N=10 detection over the proposed Taffy I system (11 pointings) with 10km/s velocity resolution, we request an rms sensitivity of 74/10 = 7.4 mJy/beam. As noted in the SJ, we need to use the ACA to retrieve extended emission over 1'.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: U12915-CO32
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes 12CO(J=3-2) over UGC12915, to trace the dense gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: From the TJ of the 12CO(J=1-0) Science Goal, the expected CO(J=1-0) flux of 74 mJy/beam for 1" beam corresponds to a brightness temperature of 7K. Assuming a typical CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ratio of 0.3, we expect the CO brightess of 7.01*0.3=0.21 K, corresponding to 200 mJy/b at 345 GHz. For S/N=10 detection, we request an rms sensitivity of 20mJy/b at 10km/s resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: U12914-CO32
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes 12CO(J=3-2) over UGC12914, to trace the dense gas.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The estimation of CO(J=3-2) is the same as the TJ for the previous Science Goal(U12915-CO32).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: U12914-HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes HCN, HCO+ and CS over UGC12914.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CS brightness is difficult to estimate as the shock state is not known, so we base our sensitivity estimate on the HCN, which is normally weaker than the HCO+. There are very few measurements of these 350GHz lines, but Papadopoulos et al. (2007) measure a HCN(J=4-3)/CO(J=3-2) ratio of 0.11 for Mrk231. We assume the same ratio of Taffy I. Since the 12CO(J=3-2) flux is estimated to be 200mJy, we estimate a HCN(J=4-3) flux of 200*0.11 = 22 mJy/b. For a S/N=5 detection, we request an rms sensitivity of 4.5 mJy/b at 10km/s resolution.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: U12915-HCN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes HCN, HCO+, CS over UGC12915.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Same as the HCN flux estimation and TJ for ScienceGoal(U12914-HCN).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map diffuse gas (CO(1-0,3-2)), dense gas (HCN,HCO+) and shock (CS) in an interacting galaxy Taffy I, to pinpoint the chronological order of events that occured in this galaxy which transformed it into a starburst, further sending it to the end of the starburst sequence on the Schmidt-Kennicutt diagram. Taffy I is a special case where the time of collision is well known (20Myr ago), due to its peculiar geometry of being a completely face on collision. Our newly obtained Pa-alpha image revealed that the star forming sites are the same age, while star formation in the bridge connecting the galaxies is exceptionally young. Currently, the starburst is confined to the disk. Our previous CO data shows signs of a massive gas infall in the northern galaxy, but could not give decisive conclusions due to the low resolution. We wish to resolve the inflow structure at 300 parsec scales in both counterparts and the bridge. This will enable us to estimate when the inflow started, when it will reach the nuclei, and how much star formation is expected, revealing the history and fate of Taffy I.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
